subject: pldm: Support bios attributes for boot types
commitMessage:
pldm: Support bios attributes for boot types

This commits adds supports to 2 bios attributes pvm_boot_initiator and
pvm_boot_type, which lets the host know who initiated the boot through
pvm_boot_initiator, and what type of boot(boot or reboot) through the
pvm_boot_type attribute.

Signed-off-by: Sagar Srinivas <sagar.srinivas@ibm.com>
Change-Id: Ic11b53a79a4fa686acf87b7d678c573601e657ed

Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)
please follow the 50/72 rule for commit messages
Done
what?
Done
Useful to log biosAttrStr as well here?
Done
The requirement as I understood it was that we set the RestorePolicy on the power off. This appears to be running on the power on (HostState.Running).
Done
This logic I would expect here, where we are powering on.
Done

I think you want to move the RestorePolicy logic from above to down here. i.e. run it on the power off. The use case is that PHYP has been notified that a power loss is eminent. They have logic to figure out if they want the RestorePolicy to be to auto power on once power is fixed so we need to set the RestorePolicy during the power off.
Ack
I don't think this code is needed. I ensure to reset the RestartCause in state-manager code (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-state-manager/+/49323).
Done
I think this should be "Off". i.e. if the system owner has requested an Off then it's a "GRACEFUL_SHUTDOWN" otherwise it some sort of reboot so a "GRACEFUL_RESTART"
Done
this will create a new bus instance, we already have getBus() singleton infrastructure to get the existing bus instance , please use the existing infra.
Done
was this being checked in the client code ?
Have added code in the client to check for emptiness
same here.
Done

does this need to be blocking ?

or do we need a  bus.call_noreply ?
Done
This is IBM Only - this should not be in the common code, please move this logic to OEM.
Done

I don't know when the _current is switched over. Should we be looking at pvm_boot_initiator to ensure we get whatever the host has set this to most recently or will _current be set correctly when we check it here?
yeah i also think the same. Pls check the pvm_boot_initiator
Done
This should be rare that the host uses this so I think an info log to the journal when we hit this path would be useful for debug.
pls add a journal trace as of now. Pavithra is making a commit to allow to create info logs. use that when available
Done
this logic is OEM only, move this to oem
Done
a state != “xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host.Transition.On”  means a reipl. pls change accordingly
if the system owner has requested an Off then it's a "GRACEFUL_SHUTDOWN" otherwise it some sort of reboot so a "GRACEFUL_RESTART"

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/Host.interface.yaml#L26

RequestedHostTransaction -> This can be an enum , and what will be the value of effecterState in other cases ? apart from those two that were being checked ?

So, if RequestedHostTransaction is anything but "xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host.Transition.Off" then it can be considered as a reboot. so the effecterState would be PLDM_SW_TERM_GRACEFUL_SHUTDOWN_REQUESTED for all the other cases.

this ideally does not seem to qualify as a good util function, as you are restricting clients to only set one attribute value at a time , which is not ideal expectation from a utility code point of view.


The cost of this is, that we would send multiple attribute value changed events to host, if we have more than a single attribute value update - which can be avoided as Pending value takes a list of bios attributes & values.

making this to take list/vector as input would be better ?
Done
nit : != nullptr is redundant. if(oemPlatformHandler) should be good enough right ?
Done

what would be the value of the attribute if the restart cause is not any of these ?

if we dont need any change in attribute value ? probably a good thing to document here ?

do you need to return ? from here ?

or you can continue ?
Done

ah, this is what i was saying in the earlier comment. this is probably not the best way to model this.

Because Pending Attributes accepts a list of Attributes , splitting this into two set call would just set that dbus value twice, there by sending the attribute value changed notification twice, which can be avoided.
Done
If the reason for this boot is a HostCrash then we are also responsible for filling in the pvm_boot_type to "ReIPL" since PHYP can not control the BIOS value when it crashes in an MIPL.
